065FCA1EC39A41AD83C11996241EE411.description: Begins to understand explanations of events that have not been experienced directly, as long as the child has had a similar experience.

164CC9E510634CB6814275DA5D337DA2.description: Increased ability to understand explanations when concrete objects and actions support the verbal explanation, and phenomena are directly observable (e.g., "When we mix colors, we get a new color. See what color you get when you mix yellow with blue.").

466040F1FCE840E59D4397941E6B0AA0.description: Becomes more animated in play (e.g., using different voices for the baby, dog, etc.).

5B0DAACE9B5540F897DA39C3F2858F03.description: Uses objects as symbolic props (e.g., places a shell on top of a dollhouse and declares it to be a satellite dish).

1A9289375EF042728C74B0F5A10755C4.description: Communicates thoughts and feelings through role play, though may still need adult support (e.g., play-acts being a kitten seeking affection and hugs).

80CF792ECE334757A69F5F5FCCB4857D.description: Engages in pretend play and acts out roles

74AE517B5EAD4107AF496D55A3A6AE54.description: Uses art to reflect thoughts and feelings (e.g., transforms a list of favorite foods that the teacher recorded on paper into a mobile from which illustrations of these foods are hung).

C3D1603198784F5BA1ABE664B74C7F7A.description: Begins to create art that is more realistic and includes some details of objects, animals, or people. Such details are typically remembered features that have made an impression but do not include all that is seen or known (e.g., draws a picture of a car with four wheels but no windows).

4987A26BC3B74CDA97C4E7F8CD9340BA.description: Represents people, places, or things through drawings, movement, and three-dimensional objects.

563C78D781F5425BAD038BCFFBE77A8F.description: Begins identifying when things are not put away in designated areas.

73DFB19CE83C442A99001A0B983D1E10.description: Recognizes and is responsible for returning items to the appropriate location with prompting.

0B2E887FF1684154823B7A70F0DE82DD.description: Begins to demonstrate appropriate use of classroom materials with modeling (e.g., using glue in an art project appropriately or turning book pages with care).

7CE5E605898645F1B5F3BEB2CE191D43.description: Helps with cleanup after activities with prompting.

45BAB1842CF244179CED428B11448ED8.description: Demonstrates appropriate use of materials or belongings and those of others.

125E8D864D13465A97958D71C441FBB9.description: Engages in out-of-the-classroom activities (i.e., recess) and successfully re-enters the classroom without disruption.

05934CDEFDC546CDB8596EDB551A611F.description: Frequently demonstrates comfort with the transition from home to the classroom environment (e.g., easily calms down when parents leave).

396A47F2DD1848C781B45BAE11084335.description: Manages separation anxiety from home to school by kissing the caregiver goodbye or waving from the window every day.

265E60293C7E47EE90BB3D51A09B89D9.description: Demonstrates the ability to adapt to new environments with appropriate behaviors with adult support.

4CAE082977A145BCBDF95D4700388887.description: Occasionally demonstrates the ability to stop an engaging activity to help clean up, requiring less support and guidance from an adult.

3391FD91EBD94B9F9151AA998BFB795C.description: Takes and gives cues to other children during transitions and models their appropriate behavior with adult support.

44CCECFA1F614C5A9CC88DE5CE02D19A.description:
Demonstrates the ability to stop
one activity and start another

070D82C246C345B3B71D744FB7CB7358.description: Requires fewer prompts to follow classroom routines and is able to independently anticipate what happens next.

A07F39D03C4445B59FAAFF8A9B4C56BC.description: Behaves appropriately within the context of classroom routines with adult modeling and support (i.e., listens when someone else is talking or raises a hand to share).

55917A014AC34B08B509C07D73AFECAA.description: Takes initiative with assigned or chosen tasks relating to classroom routines.

1D8970C5794E4E9DB3F975A57D0ABA50.description: Responds to teacher directions or signals consistently.

D9CC2AD9647B4E418745BC7E5E82DA86.description: Understanding and complying with classroom rules, routines and expectations

A6537BBD099F40D49AC003F57C782E45.description: Suggests solutions to problems with other children while continuing to seek adults' help (e.g., says, "Hey, Benjamin! We can BOTH be firemen!").

EDE638445A5D4BD38F1BBA94BD18729B.description: Begins to try to please other children (e.g., says, "You can come to my birthday party, ok?").

B01A3012E5C643CC90B5216A1B3E4304.description: Shows further progress in developing friendships with peers, even if a bond is formed with just one other child.

34CD30ED5C3D44508AEC920CBC11B700.description: Responds more appropriately and sympathetically to peers who are in need, upset, hurt, or angry (e.g., says, "Don't cry, Willy. My daddy can fix that bike. He knows how.").

CCABCECDEEC641B49F59A60E4063666F.description: Will often notice that a problem can be resolved by a change in approach (e.g., trying to fit a puzzle piece a few times and then rotating it to find a better fit).

9E98C05A087444C7ABC171F7E41145F4.description: Experiences difficulty with drawing, cutting, and writing, but persists with adult support and encouragement until the task is complete.

277381EC9DC3486CAD427A94787E359B.description: Continues to attempt to build a tower even after three or more unsuccessful attempts with adult support and encouragement.

5E9CD168EB34419D8493D91F5CA7A778.description: Will often persist in working to complete all aspects of a planned task (e.g., when building a zoo in the block area, will keep working until every animal has a cage).

AB9996B60C84485890D3BD3FABBDC812.description: Keeps working to complete a task even if it is moderately difficult (e.g., persists with a somewhat challenging wooden puzzle).

9144F63300D641A1B267D9E64763771E.description: Persists with a wider variety of tasks, activities, and experiences with adult prompting.

E8552093537C40DB966BEAEDA4A7056E.description:
Persistsinanactivity from start to finish
(complete a task) -independently

C59C55C079DB4030BB2EA9AB9C86726E.description: Develops a greater ability to set goals and follow a plan (e.g., a child says, "I'm going to pick up all these branches," and then works until the task is complete).

AC2036E39ACE4194B3072B3FACDE92EF.description: Expands decision-making skills (e.g., a child may say, "This morning, I'm going to work on my Lego building.").

BB94A0785FE542DC91FDA381DEA5F211.description: Shows interest in leading activities and taking responsibility during cleanup.

66198A1AD5EC4C6695E74794EDF29C6B.description: When prompted, initiates a plan for activities.

2387BBF130C74003826DF7DD5B580CC8.description: Independence in learning – plans and initiates projects

1C23D23E4F3A4D1CAB16F09B78B926BF.description: Seeks new and varied experiences and challenges (e.g., puts materials together in new ways to test results, joins a peer-created game or activity, tries to dress a new doll, or builds a new construction toy).

77A3833124644DF08B21465298EB95DB.description: Begins to show increased enthusiasm for learning letters, shapes, and numbers (e.g., while looking at a book with a parent, points to a word that contains the letter "S" and says, "S! That's in my name! What is that word?").

D76E917D51FE488E8BE101CA6E27D276.description: Asks questions about future events as well as about the present (e.g., asks, "When will we go to Sarah's house again?").

BE821AFB00CE4EF3A50ACDC1587DA296.description: Desire to learn – interest in challenges

9F96EA89FFCF426A8A52AF2DBE6E94A8.description: Asks to participate in new experiences they have observed or heard others talk about (e.g., says, "Janice goes fishing. Can I?").

550CC25F7A38497CA2EBB4BE4D7E5259.description: Elaborates on experiments by attempting to replicate results using different materials (e.g., gathers various materials to drop in the water table, then sorts what sinks vs. what floats).

7C4068671A1F4B8B8C8BE138CC10E46D.description: Poses questions to seek explanations about topics of interest with adult support and modeling.

8916210F09654EB1B0D8A375C11052A3.description: Asks questions about future events as well as about the present (e.g., asks, "When will we go to Val’s?").

BC49CAE0606C4D2A8AEF94E77D29C04F.description: Desire to learn – asks questions and seeks new information

4F5449F3768F48F19241231026ED15BA.description: When faced with a problem, can be reminded to slow down and think about what to do.

8B81EB0F9F6047B2ACAFAF98AA70437B.description: When in conflict with another child, is increasingly able to suggest possible solutions.

3D86962AFF154DA58496CE98AA3A5622.description: Continues to become more cognitively flexible and is able to draw on varied resources to solve problems (e.g., tries to build a large structure with blocks, but it keeps falling down. After several failed attempts, they try making a larger base. May also observe how other children have built their structures).

7305237436DD4F52B232B50039F66A29.description: Begins to employ their own solutions to problems through trial and error (e.g., tries different pegs to see which one fits).

9DBA1B76B46842129A0B062F1A9D8A98.description: Flexible problem solving-seeks multiple solutions to a question, task, or problem.

87682B57AE3F4DEF9C6E01429E6F8861.description: Able to change sorting categories with help (e.g., sorting by color, then by shape).

0805E8562B02480DB0CCC7443C40D53A.description: Often recognizes and corrects mistakes independently.

86FB5FDB475046178F863238BAF87D19.description: Can follow different rules in familiar contexts with minimal reminders (e.g., takes off shoes at home but not at school).

549AD74181834949B87D5B5243A4DA3B.description: Enjoys games like Simon Says that require following two different rules when cued (e.g., copying and not copying).

52F63321767B4848A8889C82F14E6493.description: Can switch roles in dramatic play.

01BE71D00E374EB6B0659850B9D63665.description: Can independently sustain a character in pretend play for 10 minutes or longer.

2786ECB971C245E38D3D9457D4C64516.description: Can flexibly apply rules to games and behavior

7B7E875DD95A4E09998DBE4A9ABEECF0.description:
Can enjoy more complex memory
games with more cards or objects.

1704BEEB5E824CDC9CAD66A074851831.description:
Can keep track of a few different
objects for short periods of time.

753E5CB5D5334CEAB635D0868FEC074E.description: Can hold in mind the comments of peers and respond appropriately during a short class discussion.

AB0FC776F0784702A2F454C06B312BE0.description: Can remember and follow two-step directions without prompting.

A9EED62D54F349C6842F69B08C39F9D3.description: Can remember and follow multiple classroom rules with visual and auditory cues.

0503AD518F0C4447888BA7135984F709.description: Frequently considers multiple possibilities before making a choice.

9FEB8A1BDAF94F05B49A514EA9613A91.description: Can remember recent events in a story and use this information to shape predictions and questions.

3AEF0E02C4854934A62EF6664DE73F7B.description: Demonstrate the ability to hold and manipulate information

84225884465B491EA24C44406151FB1D.description: May need a reminder to return to an earlier task after an interruption.

EA727770CE294CA295C90477EC101B2D.description: Remains on task during a teacher-set activity for short periods despite distractions, with minimal prompting from adults (e.g., can ignore nearby activities and maintain focus on a teacher-directed small group activity).

CA22D9DF662E45EA857FF55B1D0A185C.description: Attentiveness – Resists distraction to maintain focus on tasks set by someone else

80D739087CA444E584C34A3B6F848AA0.description: Capable of sustaining focus on longer-term or complex projects with support from an adult.

8618DE57B82245D48C56F994BC82FB55.description: Increases ability to ignore distractions and sustain attention on topics of interest (e.g., can focus on a drawing even when other children are nearby; might say, “I’ll play with you later. I want to finish this.”).

C953395C981543B4813EDCA499E9A9EC.description: Attentiveness – Resists distraction to maintain focus on tasks of interest to the child

B7FDCEC1360649B98C9233E8DA9B0702.description: Learns coping strategies (e.g., using words, pretend play, drawing) to establish greater control and competence in managing intense emotions (e.g., after going to the emergency room, a child may repeatedly play out the experience with dolls and stuffed animals) resist impulses to harm self, others, or property.

C10272BCEA0D468DAF7DE93F8487B52E.description: Can wait for a highly desired food or object, though may occasionally need reminders.

1546C9D24FFB4CE395A8A5FF73EFF1E5.description: Able to take turns with preferred toys or classroom materials (e.g., waits for an object without grabbing, with minimal prompting).

EFA58763273841B5A826D723DA9DF6B0.description: Independently waits for an object without grabbing most of the time.

CACD42DB4EED45DEBB62A8EE2E236BDD.description: Able to play games like Red Light, Green Light that require waiting for a signal to act, with adult support.

F423B96A8E2F4A8F97501E413FCD74EC.description: Sometimes able to resist habits when they are no longer appropriate (e.g., may remember while walking to the bathroom that the paper towels have moved and adjust accordingly).

EAA99E1EAF9447D9A4F63A8941DFAAC5.description: Can play the role of a teacher in a game, monitor other children’s behavior, and remind them to follow the rules.

C8C69C7E0B4F46BD816BDC0D00B40DB1.description: More reliably controls impulses during structured activities that are familiar (e.g., raising a hand to talk).

8C97E270412249EDBE6C4B3A7D1085FF.description: Avoids imitating the negative behavior of peers with minimal prompting from adults.

37A74D0A87734D85B229DFF013CC9783.description: Has an awareness of conflict resolution strategies but is not yet able to implement them consistently (e.g., understands a story where a social strategy was used but struggles to apply it functionally).

8CEF18937A7947AD899BF1AFF918AEF3.description: Discusses possible solutions with peers with adult assistance.

C7918FC2CC62457CB8E1A06F143831A5.description: Seeks adult help when solving interpersonal conflicts.

A7FDC1B5E423489F8BA7BA0AB56E064B.description: Identifies interpersonal conflicts and begins to manage emotions more effectively using self-talk with adult support and modeling (e.g., “Take three deep breaths, and then ask Caleb for another turn.”).

77931234BF7244D3A7218EA836BEFC14.description: Identifies and negotiates when a peer is not given the same instructions or structure (e.g., “William’s mommy lets him watch Dora. Why can’t I?”).

3C391FEFAD1248188DE08BF65D4EDF45.description: Identifies differences or similarities between self and others (e.g., children with disabilities, gender, hair color, etc.).

AC206CC8B0CF45108ED0C8DF59B6B266.description: Recognizes differences or similarities between self as compared to others

905F87F8C9C94E99B22048526A83A0A7.description: Shares materials and equipment with other children with adult modeling and support.

ECE606647EC443428B681A1AAF7537E7.description: Has one or more special friendships.

162DFE8C44884298AE4407A35B6D2184.description: Plays or works with others cooperatively

EDDEA0900FAE48F1B0757B51868ACFBB.description: Shows concern for peers who are upset or hurt.

3D6AAFCA58164361BF07A20372762143.description: Seeks adult assistance for classmates who need support.

7587B01198B64E1DB694A5F4798F0CC3.description: Understands a wider array of feelings (e.g., frustrated, scared, lonely) and expresses them to others.

772677AE718B498E8D05CBE9583A87E7.description: Communicates negative and positive emotions verbally and responds to teacher prompts or directions.

1C41558ABB384DA6959633390B75FD11.description: Expresses, understands, and responds to feelings(emotions) of others

EFE71A3C78454C619CE5DCBA05CBBA56.description: Requires fewer prompts to follow classroom routines and can independently anticipate what happens next.

6F4AD780F29D44F68521FF430A3617A4.description: Seeks new and varied experiences and challenges (e.g., puts materials together in new ways to test results; joins a peer-created game or activity).

048B8BD6CFFA41C4A2E069279C59341A.description: Essential Skills and Knowledge: Demonstrates independence in a range of routines and tasks
